block.p: Car Bombs Kill 41, Most of Them Children A pair of car bombs tore through a street celebration marking the opening of a new sewer plant, killing 41 Iraqis, at least 34 of them children, and wounding and maiming 139 more, in one of the most horrific attacks in Baghdad since the fall of Saddam Hussein.
American and Iraqi soldiers launched a military assault on Samarra, in what appeared to be the first major operation to retake areas from rebels before elections.

The Bush administration is pressing wealthy countries to come up with money to help fill the gap created by its recent decision to divert funds in Iraq from reconstruction into security and job creation.
Eroding Kurdish Gains in Turkey Kurds have begun to achieve a modicum of economic progress and cultural freedom, but at the same time, Kurdish militants have taken up arms in southeastern Turkey.

31 Killed in Israeli Offensive At least 28 Palestinians and three Israelis were killed as Israeli troops pushed into a refugee camp in the Gaza Strip and battled militants. The fighting, combined with warnings from Israeli officials, pointed to the possibility of a large-scale military offensive in Gaza directed at the Palestinian factions responsible for almost daily attacks.
Russian Global Warming Treaty Russia's cabinet endorsed the long-delayed Kyoto Protocol on global warming treaty and sent it to parliament.

Secretary General Front-runner Thailand's foreign minister, Surakiart Sathirathai, has emerged as an early favorite to succeed Kofi Annan as United Nations secretary general when his term ends in 2006.

Bush and Kerry Clash Over Iraq in Debate Senator John Kerry, in his first face-to-face encounter with President Bush, argued last night that Mr. Bush had made a ''colossal error of judgment'' in invading Iraq, while Mr. Bush belittled Mr. Kerry as a weak leader whose shifting opinions would embolden America's foes.

Panel Critical of DeLay The House ethics committee determined that the majority leader, Tom DeLay, should be admonished for improperly trying to win the vote of a Michigan lawmaker during a floor fight over a health bill.
Airport Security Increased Officials began photographing and electronically fingerprinting travelers from 27 industrialized nations, including England and France.
Drug Bills Vetoed in California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger vetoed several bills that would have made the state the middleman in large-scale purchases of prescription drugs from Canada.
Cuban Scholars Denied Visas The Bush administration has denied entry to all 61 Cuban scholars scheduled to participate in an international congress in Las Vegas.

Ban on Gay Unions Blocked A proposed constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage failed in the House of Representatives, a defeat the measure's Republican backers promptly vowed to wield against Democrats in the November election.

Deportation Delayed for Hamdi The administration postponed deporting Yaser E. Hamdi, the Saudi-American captured in Afghanistan in 2001, because of Saudi government objections to requirements that it monitor him for five years.

Mayor Demands Inquiry Into Ex-Senator's Release Mayor Bloomberg said he asked the New York City Department of Investigation to examine how a city commission run by mayoral appointees granted former State Senator Guy J. Velella an early release from jail.

Law Firms Must Defend Fees A New York State judge told law firms that they must justify the contingency fees they charged to represent families before the federal September 11th Victim Compensation Fund. She left open the possibility that she might reduce them.

Woman, 76, Fatally Stabbed A 76-year-old Brooklyn woman fought back against a robber who stabbed her half a dozen times, but died after staggering two blocks into a police station and collapsing on the floor, the authorities said.
Obesity Deemed Societal Ill A report on the causes and solutions for childhood obesity in the United States calls for a societal strategy, including healthier meals in schools and restaurants.
Arthritis Drug Withdrawn Merck said it would stop selling its arthritis and pain medication Vioxx because a new study found that it doubled patients' risk of heart attack and strokes.
U.S. Willing to Forgive Debt The United States and is nearing an agreement with international financial institutions to forgive all the government debts of many of the world's poorest countries.

Trade Dispute Unresolved Top trade officials for the United States and the European Union failed to resolve their dispute over government subsidies to aircraft manufacturers, inching closer to a clash.
Fannie Mae Investigation The Justice Department started an investigation of Fannie Mae in response to a report accusing executives of sloppy accounting practices, a government official said.
Editorials: The first debate; ending the cycle of debt; demise of a blockbuster drug; not in America.
